More than 100 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green were arrested last month, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. Vowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.The protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. Vowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. {"uri": "8114132821", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:28:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:28:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:26:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.breitbart.com/news/columbia-university-cancels-main-commencement-after-weeks-of-pro-palestinian-protests/", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests - Breitbart", "body": "Columbia University says it is canceling its university-wide commencement ceremony following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests but will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next\n\nColumbia University cancels main commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protestsBy KAREN MATTHEWSAssociated PressThe Associated PressNEW YORK\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Columbia University is canceling its large university-wide commencement ceremony following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but it will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next, the school announced Monday.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in a statement.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the school said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students. \"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement Sunday in Fenway Park.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. The student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.", "source": {"uri": "breitbart.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breitbart"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-346691278", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:46:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:46:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:11:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/columbia-university-cancels-main-commencement-after-weeks-of-pro-palestinian-protests/article_d05e90de-77f5-557c-b857-3b7ed28a78c0.html", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests", "body": "Columbia University says it is canceling its university-wide commencement ceremony following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests but will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Columbia University is canceling its large university-wide commencement ceremony following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but it will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next, the school announced Monday.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in a statement.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the school said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students. \"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement Sunday in Fenway Park.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. The student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.\n\nMore from this section\n\nStriking deals to end campus protests, some colleges invite discussion of their investments A look at commencement ceremonies as US campuses are roiled by protests over the Israel-Hamas war Stack Sports launches Stack Rewards to Save Youth Sports Families $100M", "source": (AP Photo/Yuki Iwamura, File)\n\nColumbia University is canceling its large university-wide commencement ceremony amid ongoing pro-Palestinian protests but will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next, the university announced Monday.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in a statement.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the school said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students. \"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 100 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green were arrested last month, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but it will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next, the school announced Monday.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in a statement.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. {"uri": "2024-05-346662521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:19:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:19:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:08:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.trentonian.com/2024/05/06/columbia-university-cancels-main-commencement-after-weeks-of-pro-palestinian-protests/", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Columbia University is canceling its large university-wide commencement ceremony following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but it will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next, the school announced Monday.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in a statement.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the school said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students. \"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement Sunday in Fenway Park.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. The student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.", "source": {"uri": "trentonian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Trentonian"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8114106805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:07:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:07:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:07:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://english.aawsat.com/node/5003496", "title": "Columbia University Cancels Main Commencement after Weeks of Pro-Palestinian Protests", "body": "Police stand guard near an encampment of protesters supporting Palestinians on the grounds of Columbia University, during the ongoing conflict between Israel and the Palestinian group Hamas, in New York City, US, April 30, 2024. (Reuters)\n\nColumbia University is canceling its large university-wide commencement ceremony following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the US, but it will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next, the school announced Monday.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in a statement.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the school said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students. \"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement Sunday in Fenway Park.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas gunmen attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. The student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. {"uri": "2024-05-346641418", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:01:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:01:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:11:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/nation/columbia-university-cancels-main-commencement-after-weeks-of-pro-palestinian-protests/article_892ec6b8-0900-500d-909c-2961171242f6.html", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests", "body": "CORRECTS CAPTION TO NYPD ARREST PRO-PALESTINIAN DEMONSTRATORS New York Police Department officers arrest pro-Palestinian demonstrators on 114th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Tuesday night, April 30, 2024, in New York. The NYPD also stormed Columbia University's campus after Columbia University President Minouche Shafik called on the department to dismantle encampments and remove individuals from Hamilton Hall.\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Columbia University is canceling its large university-wide commencement ceremony following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but it will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next, the school announced Monday.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in a statement.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the school said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students. \"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement Sunday in Fenway Park.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. The student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement Sunday in Fenway Park.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. The student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. In Boston, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags during a graduation ceremony for Northeastern University Sunday in Fenway Park.\n\nThe protests are due to the conflict that started Israel or contribute to the war effort, per the AP.\n\nIsrael launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the {"uri": "8113876535", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:32:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:32:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:29:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13387363/Columbia-University-cancels-main-commencement-protests-roiled-campus-weeks.html", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement after protests that...", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) - Columbia University is canceling its large university-wide commencement ceremony amid ongoing pro-Palestinian protests but will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next, the university announced Monday.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in a statement.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the school said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students. \"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school\u00b4s invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia\u00b4s sports complex, officials said.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 100 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia\u00b4s green were arrested last month, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nFILE - Pro-Israel demonstrators gather for the \"Bring Them Home Now\" rally outside the Columbia University, April 26, 2024, in New York. Pro-Palestinian protesters have dominated university quads in the last two weeks, shutting down colleges and clashing with riot police. But there's been a notable scarcity of student rallies in solidarity with Israelis. (AP Photo/Yuki Iwamura, File)\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. Vowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.\n\nStaff members of the Columbia Daily Spectator, the college newspaper, work into the night as police cleared out demonstrators from Columbia University's campus, late Tuesday, April 30, 2024, in New York. {"uri": "8113886693", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:37:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:37:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:36:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/us-news/columbia-cancels-main-graduation-ceremony-after-weeks-of-anti-israel-protests-on-campus-101715001614818.html", "title": "Columbia cancels main graduation ceremony after weeks of anti-Israel protests on campus", "body": "Columbia University is canceling its large university-wide commencement ceremony amid ongoing pro-Palestinian protests but will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next, the university announced Monday.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in a statement.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the school said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students. \"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 100 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green were arrested last month, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. Vowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.\n\nAnti-war demonstrations ceased this week at a small number of U.S. universities after school leaders struck deals with pro-Palestinian protesters, fending off possible disruptions of final exams and graduation ceremonies.\n\nThe agreements at schools including Brown, Northwestern and Rutgers stand out amid the chaotic scenes and 2,400-plus arrests on 46 campuses nationwide since April 17. Tent encampments and building takeovers have disrupted classes at some schools, including Columbia and UCLA.\n\nDeals included commitments by universities to review their investments in Israel or hear calls to stop doing business with the longtime U.S. ally. Many protester demands have zeroed in on links to the Israeli military as the war grinds on in Gaza.\n\nThe agreements to even discuss divestment mark a major shift on an issue that has been controversial for years, with opponents of a long-running campaign to boycott Israel saying it veers into antisemitism. But while the colleges have made concessions around amnesty for protesters and funding for Middle Eastern studies, they have made no promises about changing their investments.", "source": {"uri": on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in a statement.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the school said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students. \"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nThe Education Lab\n\nReceive our in-depth coverage of education issues and stories that affect North Texans.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement Sunday in Fenway Park.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. The student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. universities around the US.\n\nStudents have called for a ceasefire in Gaza and have demanded their schools divest from companies with ties to Israel.\n\nNew York City police cleared a Columbia campus building last week that had been barricaded by pro-Palestinian protesters, arresting more than 100 people and dismantling an encampment.\n\nThe school said on Monday it had consulted with student Students have called for a ceasefire in Gaza and have demanded their schools divest from companies with ties to Israel.\n\nSome universities, including Columbia, called in riot police wielding batons and flash-bang grenades to disperse and arrest hundreds of protesters, citing a paramount need for campus safety. Civil rights groups have decried such tactics as unnecessarily violent infringements on free speech.\n\nRead moreColumbia University president in hot water over handling of pro-Palestinian protests\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the school said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students.\n\n\"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" the statement noted. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nCeremonies scrapped in California universities\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nColumbia had already cancelled in-person classes.\n\nThe University of Southern California (USC) earlier cancelled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nAt the University of California, Los Angeles, (UCLA) where pro-Israeli and pro-Palestinian protesters clashed last week and where police arrested more than 200 people, Chancellor Gene Block on Sunday announced a new Office of Campus Safety.\n\nA former Sacramento, {"uri": "8113969370", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:31:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:31:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:31:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/06/columbia-university-cancels-commencement-after-weeks-of-pro-palestinian-protests/", "title": "Columbia University cancels commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests", "body": "Staff members of the Columbia Daily Spectator, the college newspaper, work into the night as police cleared out demonstrators from Columbia University's campus, late Tuesday, April 30, 2024, in New York. Left to right; Isabella Ramirez, editor in chief; Esha Karam, managing editor; Yvin Shin, head copy editor; Emily Forgash, deputy news editor; and Shea Vance, university news editor. AP Photo/Jake Offenhartz\n\nNEW YORK -- Columbia University is canceling its large university-wide commencement ceremony following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but it will hold smaller school-based ceremonies this week and next, the school announced Monday.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in a statement.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the school said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students. \"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nStudent protesters camp near the entrance to Hamilton Hall on the campus of Columbia University, Tuesday, April 30, 2024, in New York. AP Photo/Mary Altaffer, Pool\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nRelated Troops fired on Kent State students in 1970. Survivors see echoes in today's campus protests\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement Sunday in Fenway Park.\n\nPro-Israel demonstrators gather for the \"Bring Them Home Now\" rally outside the Columbia University, April 26, 2024, in New York. AP Photo/Yuki Iwamura, File\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. The student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.\n\nCopy the Story Link Related Headlines College protests. A Trump trial. Raging wars. Is everything 'on fire'? The decision comes amidst a backdrop of escalating tensions but will see smaller school-based ceremonies proceeding as planned over the coming weeks.\n\nOfficials at the prestigious Ivy League institution in upper Manhattan revealed on Monday that the cancellation of the university-wide ceremony, slated for May 15, is a result of consultations with students, news agency AP reported. They emphasised that the move reflects the desires of the student body, who expressed a preference for more intimate, school-level celebrations.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, and to forego the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" officials at the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan stated.\n\n\"Based on feedback from our students, we have decided to focus attention on our Class Days and school-level graduation ceremonies,\" stated university officials, as quoted by AP. \"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families. They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nALSO READ | Columbia To Yale: Why Protests Have Erupted On US College Campuses Over Gaza War\n\nIn-Person Classes Canceled Amid Pro-Palestinian Protests\n\nThe decision follows weeks of heightened tensions on campus, with the university already having canceled in-person classes. Pro-Palestinian demonstrators, numbering over 100, were arrested last month after camping out on Columbia's green. Similar protests have erupted at universities across the US, as institutions grapple with balancing free expression and campus safety.\n\nThe move by Columbia mirrors actions taken by the University of Southern California (USC), which recently canceled its main graduation ceremony due to similar protests. USC students vacated their encampment early Sunday under threat of arrest after being surrounded by law enforcement.\n\nThe protests have been sparked by the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas, which began on October 7. Hamas militants' attacks on southern Israel led to Israeli retaliatory strikes in Gaza. {"uri": "8114387431", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "20:07:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T20:07:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T20:06:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/nation-and-world/columbia-cancels-main-commencement-after-weeks-of-protests-3046113/", "title": "Columbia cancels main commencement after weeks of protests", "body": "NEW YORK -- Columbia University canceled its large university-wide commencement ceremony Monday following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the United States, but said students will still be able to celebrate at a series of smaller, school-based ceremonies this week and next.\n\nThe decision comes as universities around the country are wrangling with how to handle commencements.\n\nAnother campus shaken by protests, Emory University, announced Monday that it would move its commencement from its campus quadrangle in Atlanta to a suburban arena. But others, including the University of Michigan, Indiana University and Northeastern, have pulled off ceremonies with few disruptions.\n\nColumbia's decision to cancel its main ceremonies scheduled for May 15 saves its president, Minouche Shafik, from having to deliver a commencement address in the same part of campus where police dismantled a protest encampment last week.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students.\n\n\"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nSpeakers at some of Columbia's still-scheduled graduation ceremonies include Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright James Ijames, former CNN anchor Poppy Harlow, political scientist Ian Bremmer and Dr. Monica Bertagnolli, director of the National Institutes of Health.\n\nAlso, actor Michael J. Fox is scheduled to receive a medal for distinguished service from Columbia's Teachers College.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks.\n\nSimilar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC on Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston on Sunday, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement in Fenway Park.\n\nAt the University of California, Los Angeles, disruptions continued Monday following the dismantling of a pro-Palestinian encampment and some 200 arrests last week. Police detained numerous people in a parking structure. The university also said classes in one building, Monroe Hall, would move online \"due to ongoing disruptions\" but did not provide details.\n\nAlso Monday, police cleared a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of California, San Diego, and arrested more than 30 people, The San Diego Union-Tribune reported.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas terrorists attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. Student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nHamas announced Monday that it has accepted an Egyptian-Qatari cease-fire proposal to halt the war in Gaza, but Israel did not immediately comment. Details have not yet been released.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an retaliatory offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, according to the Hamas-run Health Ministry in Gaza.\n\nEmory's 16,000-student university is one of many that has seen repeated protests over the war.\n\nCeremonies scheduled for May 13 will now be held at the GasSouth Arena and Convocation Center in Duluth, almost 20 miles northeast of the university's Atlanta campus, President Gregory Fenves said in an open letter.\n\n\"Please know that this decision was not taken lightly,\" Fenves wrote. \"It was made in close consultation with the Emory Police Department, security advisors and other agencies -- each of which advised against holding commencement events on our campuses.\"\n\nThe university called outside police agencies to arrest 28 people after an encampment was erected on the quad on April 25. Protests have continued on the campus since then, including some additional arrests.", "source": {"uri": "reviewjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Las Vegas Review-Journal"}, "authors": [], Our Deans and other colleagues who work directly with our students have been discussing plans with student leaders, and, most importantly, listening. Based on their feedback, we have decided to make the centerpiece of our Commencement activities our Class Days and school-level ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, rather than the University-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15.\n\nOur students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families. They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers. As a result, we will focus our resources on those school ceremonies and on keeping them safe, respectful, and running smoothly.\n\nThe announcement also stated:\n\nThese past few weeks have been incredibly difficult for our community. Just as we are focused on making our graduation experience truly special, we continue to solicit student feedback and are looking at the possibility of a festive event on May 15 to take the place of the large, formal ceremony.\n\nPro-Palestine protests at Columbia University resulted in a fraught, sometimes toxic environment for students as the pitch of the tone became more and more heightened and the threat of police action loomed. Encampments on campus were eventually cleared by law enforcement on April 30 after protestors -- some students, some not -- occupied Hamilton Hall. {"uri": "2024-05-346785319", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:25:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:25:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:16:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/columbia-university-cancels-main-commencement-after-weeks-of-pro-palestinian-protests-1.6874995", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests", "body": "Columbia University canceled its large university-wide commencement ceremony Monday following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but said students will still be able to celebrate at a series of smaller, school-based ceremonies this week and next.\n\nThe decision comes as universities around the country are wrangling with how to handle commencements. Another campus shaken by protests, Emory University, announced Monday that it would move its commencement from its campus quadrangle in Atlanta to a suburban arena. But others, including the University of Michigan, Indiana University and Northeastern, have pulled off ceremonies with few disruptions.\n\nColumbia's decision to cancel its main ceremonies scheduled for May 15 saves its president, Nemat Shafik, from having to deliver a commencement address in the same part of campus where police dismantled a protest encampment last week.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students.\n\n\"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles (8 kilometers) north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nSpeakers at some of Columbia's still-scheduled graduation ceremonies include Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright James Ijames, former CNN anchor Poppy Harlow, political scientist Ian Bremmer and Dr. Monica Bertagnolli, director of the National Institutes of Health. Also, actor Michael J. Fox is scheduled to receive a medal for distinguished service from Columbia's Teachers College.\n\nColumbia had already cancelled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks, and similar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC early Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston on Sunday, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement in Fenway Park.\n\nAt the University of California, Los Angeles, disruptions continued Monday following the dismantling of a pro-Palestinian encampment and some 200 arrests last week. Police detained numerous people in a parking structure. The university also said classes held in one building, Monroe Hall, would move online \"due to ongoing disruptions\" but did not provide details.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. Student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nHamas announced Monday that it has accepted an Egyptian-Qatari proposal for a cease-fire to halt the war in Gaza. There was no immediate comment from Israel on the deal, and details of the proposal have not yet been released.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.\n\nEmory's 16,000-student university is one of many that has seen repeated protests over the war.\n\nCeremonies scheduled for May 13 will now be held at the GasSouth Arena and Convocation Center in Duluth, almost 20 miles (30 kilometers) northeast of the university's Atlanta campus, President Gregory Fenves said in an open letter.\n\n\"Please know that this decision was not taken lightly,\" Fenves wrote. \"It was made in close consultation with the Emory Police Department, security advisors and other agencies -- each of which advised against holding commencement events on our campuses.\"\n\nThe university called outside police agencies to arrest 28 people after an encampment was erected on the quad on April 25. After initially claiming the protesters were outsiders, the university later said 20 were Emory students and three were faculty members. Police used pepper balls and electric stun guns to subdue some of the people who were arrested. Fenves later apologized.\n\nProtests have continued on the campus since then, including some additional arrests.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": {"uri": "8113911816", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:53:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:53:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:52:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/education/2929260-columbia-cancels-university-wide-commencement-ceremony-after-protests", "title": "Columbia cancels university-wide commencement ceremony after protests | Education", "body": "\"We have decided to make the centerpiece of our commencement activities our Class Days and school-level ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, rather than the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" Columbia said in a statement, calling the past few weeks \"incredibly difficult for our community.\" The protests at Columbia, which drew national attention, have inspired similar demonstrations at dozens of universities around the U.S. Students have called for a ceasefire in Gaza and have demanded their schools divest from companies with ties to Israel.\n\nColumbia University on Monday canceled its main, university-wide commencement ceremony scheduled for May 15 in favor of smaller, school-based events, a decision that follows weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that roiled the Ivy League School. \"We have decided to make the centerpiece of our commencement activities our Class Days and school-level ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, rather than the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" Columbia said in a statement, calling the past few weeks \"incredibly difficult for our community.\"\n\nThe protests at Columbia, which drew national attention, have inspired similar demonstrations at dozens of universities around the U.S. Students have called for a ceasefire in Gaza and have demanded their schools divest from companies with ties to Israel. Some universities, including Columbia, called in riot police wielding batons and flash-bang grenades to disperse and arrest hundreds of protesters, citing a paramount need for campus safety. Civil rights groups have decried such tactics as unnecessarily violent infringements on free speech.\n\nMore than 34,600 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's military operations in Gaza, according to health officials in the Hamas-ruled Palestinian enclave. The war began when Hamas militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and abducting 252 others, of whom 133 are believed to remain in captivity in Gaza, according to Israeli tallies. The turmoil on campuses has prompted several colleges and universities across the country to relocate, modify, or cancel commencement ceremonies altogether.\n\nIn April, the University of Southern California also called off its main-stage ceremony, one week after canceling the valedictorian speech by a Muslim student who said she was silenced by anti-Palestinian hatred. Columbia said on Monday it had consulted with student leaders in deciding how to handle graduation. The majority of the ceremonies, which had been set to take place on its upper Manhattan campus, where most of the protests have taken place, will take place at the main athletic complex about five miles away.\n\nNew York City police cleared a Columbia campus building last week that had been barricaded by pro-Palestinian protesters, arresting more than 100 people and dismantling an encampment. At the University of California, Los Angeles, where pro-Israeli and pro-Palestinian protesters clashed last week and where police arrested more than 200 people while clearing a pro-Palestinian encampment on Thursday, Chancellor Gene Block on Sunday announced a new Office of Campus Safety.\n\nA former Sacramento, California, police chief, Rick Braziel, will lead the office and report directly to Block.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": The encampment that sprang up at the New York City campus has inspired activists to launch similar protest campaigns at other schools around the U.S. and internationally.\n\nIn announcing the decision to \"forego\" the university-wide commencement ceremony, Columbia said students had said that smaller-scale celebrations are \"most meaningful to them.\" \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers,\" the statement read. {"uri": "8114052578", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:30:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:30:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T15:29:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2929383-columbia-university-cancels-main-commencement-ceremony-after-protests", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement ceremony after protests | Law-Order", "body": "\"We have decided to make the centerpiece of our commencement activities our Class Days and school-level ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, rather than the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" Columbia said in a statement, calling the past few weeks \"incredibly difficult for our community.\" The protests at Columbia, which drew national attention, have inspired similar demonstrations at dozens of universities around the U.S. Students have called for a ceasefire in Gaza and have demanded their schools divest from companies with ties to Israel.\n\nColumbia University on Monday canceled its main, university-wide commencement ceremony scheduled for May 15 in favor of smaller, school-based events, a decision that follows weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that roiled the Ivy League School. \"We have decided to make the centerpiece of our commencement activities our Class Days and school-level ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, rather than the university-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" Columbia said in a statement, calling the past few weeks \"incredibly difficult for our community.\"\n\nThe protests at Columbia, which drew national attention, have inspired similar demonstrations at dozens of universities around the U.S. Students have called for a ceasefire in Gaza and have demanded their schools divest from companies with ties to Israel. Some universities, including Columbia, called in riot police wielding batons and flash-bang grenades to disperse and arrest hundreds of protesters, citing a paramount need for campus safety. Civil rights groups have decried such tactics as unnecessarily violent infringements on free speech.\n\nMore than 34,600 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's military operations in Gaza, according to health officials in the Hamas-ruled Palestinian enclave. The war began when Hamas militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and abducting 252 others, of whom 133 are believed to remain in captivity in Gaza, according to Israeli tallies. The turmoil on campuses has prompted several colleges and universities across the United States to relocate, modify, or cancel commencement ceremonies altogether.\n\nIn April, the University of Southern California also called off its main-stage ceremony, one week after canceling the valedictorian speech by a Muslim student who said she was silenced by anti-Palestinian hatred. Columbia said on Monday it had consulted with student leaders in deciding how to handle graduation. The majority of the ceremonies, which had been set to take place on its upper Manhattan campus, where most of the protests have taken place, will take place at the main athletic complex about five miles (8 km) away.\n\nThe demonstrations have emerged as a political flashpoint during a contentious U.S. election year as Democratic President Joe Biden and Republican former U.S President Donald Trump face off in rematch for the White House. Republican U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Mike Johnson -- who\n\ncondemned Columbia's administrators, accusing them of being too lenient on demonstrators during a campus visit in April -- blasted them again on Monday, saying the decision to cancel commencement denied thousands of graduates the recognition they deserved.\n\nJohnson also called on the school's board of trustees to remove university President Nemat Minouche Shafik, adding that the cancellation showed she would rather \"cede control to Hamas supporters than restore order.\" New York City police cleared a Columbia building last week that had been barricaded by pro-Palestinian protesters, arresting more than 100 people in and around the campus and dismantling an encampment.\n\nAt the University of California, Los Angeles, where pro-Israeli and pro-Palestinian protesters clashed last week and where police arrested more than 200 people while clearing a pro-Palestinian encampment on Thursday, Chancellor Gene Block on Sunday announced a new Office of Campus Safety. A former Sacramento, California, police chief, Rick Braziel, will lead the office and report directly to Block.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a "freq": 2}], "sentiment": 0.1215686274509804, "wgt": 177, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8114374492", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "19:55:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T19:55:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T19:54:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.bangordailynews.com/2024/05/06/nation/columbia-university-cancels-main-commencement-after-weeks-of-pro-palestinian-protests/", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Columbia University canceled its large university-wide commencement ceremony Monday following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but said students will still be able to celebrate at a series of smaller, school-based ceremonies this week and next.\n\nThe decision comes as universities around the country wrangle with how to handle commencements. Another campus shaken by protests, Emory University, announced Monday that it would move its commencement from its Atlanta campus to a suburban arena. But others, including the University of Michigan, Indiana University and Northeastern, have pulled off ceremonies with few disruptions.\n\nColumbia's decision to cancel its main ceremonies scheduled for May 15 saves its president, Minouche Shafik, from having to deliver a commencement address in the same part of campus where police dismantled a protest encampment last week.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said it made the decision after discussions with students.\n\n\"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles (8 kilometers) north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nSpeakers at some of Columbia's still-scheduled graduation ceremonies include Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright James Ijames, former CNN anchor Poppy Harlow, political scientist Ian Bremmer and Dr. Monica Bertagnolli, director of the National Institutes of Health. Also, actor Michael J. Fox is scheduled to receive a medal for distinguished service from Columbia's Teachers College.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks.\n\nSimilar encampments sprouted up elsewhere as universities struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities. Students abandoned their camp at USC on Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday. In Boston on Sunday, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags at Northeastern University's commencement in Fenway Park.\n\nThe University of California, Los Angeles, alerted students Monday that all classes were moving online due to ongoing disruptions following the dismantling of a pro-Palestinian encampment last week. The university police force reported 44 arrests but there were no specific details, UCLA spokesperson Eddie North-Hager said in an email to The Associated Press.\n\nAlso Monday, police cleared a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of California, San Diego, and arrested more than 30 people, The San Diego Union-Tribune reported.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. Student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nHamas announced Monday that it accepted an Egyptian-Qatari cease-fire proposal to halt the war in Gaza, but there was no immediate word from Israel, leaving it uncertain whether a deal had been sealed.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.\n\nEmory's 16,000-student university is one of many that has seen repeated protests over the war.\n\nCeremonies scheduled for May 13 will now be held at the GasSouth Arena and Convocation Center in Duluth, almost 20 miles (30 kilometers) northeast of the university's Atlanta campus, President Gregory Fenves said in an open letter.\n\n\"Please know that this decision was not taken lightly,\" Fenves wrote. \"It was made in close consultation with the Emory Police Department, security advisors and other agencies -- each of which advised against holding commencement events on our campuses.\"\n\nThe university called outside police agencies to arrest 28 people after an encampment was erected on the campus quadrangle on April 25. After initially claiming the protesters were outsiders, the university later said 20 were Emory students and three were faculty members. Police used pepper balls and electric stun guns to subdue some of the people who were arrested. Fenves later apologized.\n\nProtests have continued on the campus since then, including some additional arrests.\n\nSchools are trying various tactics from appeasement to threat of disciplinary action to get protestors to take down encampments or move to campus areas where demonstrations would be less intrusive.\n\nThe School of the Art Institute of Chicago said in a Facebook post Sunday that it offered protesters \"amnesty from academic sanction and trespassing charges\" if they moved.\n\n\"Many protesters left the premises of their own accord after being notified by the police that they were trespassing and subject to arrest,\" the school said. \"Those that remained were arrested after multiple warnings to leave, including some of whom we recognized as SAIC students.\"\n\nA group of faculty and staff members at University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill asked the administration for amnesty for any students who were arrested and suspended during recent protests. UNC Faculty and Staff for Justice in Palestine said in a media advisory that it would deliver a letter on behalf of more than 500 faculty who support the student activists.\n\nOther universities took a different approach.\n\nHarvard University's interim president, Alan Garber, warned student's Monday that those participating in a pro-Palestinian encampment in Harvard Yard could face \"involuntary leave.\" That means they may would not be allowed on campus, could lose their student housing and may not be able to take exams, Garber said.\n\nAt the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, police restricted access to an encampment after a school deadline for them to leave had passed. About 200 protesters gathered outside the camp, chanting \"MIT can't you see? Palestine will be free\" and other slogans.\n\n__\n\nAssociated Press writer Jeff Amy in Atlanta contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nThis story has been amended to change the first name of the president of Columbia University to reflect her preference, Minouche.", "source": {"uri": "bangordailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bangor Daily News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@bangordailynews.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palestinian_nationalism", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "2024-05-346537096", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "13:27:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T13:27:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:17:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/new-york-columbia-university-cancels-main-graduation-ceremony-after-weeks-of-pro-palestine-protests-2535939-2024-05-06", "title": "Columbia University cancels graduation ceremony after weeks of Gaza protests", "body": "Students march and rally on Columbia University campus in support of a protest encampment supporting Palestinians. Source: Reuters\n\nColumbia University on Monday cancelled its university-wide graduation ceremony in favour of smaller, school-based events after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests roiled the Ivy League School.\n\nAccording to the news agency Reuters, the graduation ceremony, which was scheduled for May 15, was cancelled due to the ongoing pro-Palestinian protests, adding that the past few weeks were \"incredibly difficult for our community.\"\n\n\"\"We have decided to make the centerpiece of our commencement activities our Class Days and school-level ceremonies, where students are honored individually alongside their peers, rather than the University-wide ceremony that is scheduled for May 15,\" Columbia said in a statement, calling the past few weeks \"incredibly difficult for
