{"eng-9542834": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8114434460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "20:55:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T20:55:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T20:53:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/partners/ap/national/columbia-university-cancels-main-commencement-after-weeks-of-pro-palestinian-protests/article_b62f2196-e62f-5ba1-9809-5e2ae97af167.html", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests", "body": "By KAREN MATTHEWS - Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Columbia University canceled its large university-wide commencement ceremony Monday following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but said students will still be able to celebrate at a series of smaller, school-based ceremonies this week and next.\n\nThe decision comes as universities around the country are wrangling with how to handle commencements. Another campus shaken by protests, Emory University, announced Monday that it would move its commencement from its campus quadrangle in Atlanta to a suburban arena. But others, including the University of Michigan, Indiana University and Northeastern, have pulled off ceremonies with few disruptions.\n\nWentzville superintendent's departure came after threats and police patrols Washington University faculty placed on leave, students 'houseless' after Gaza protest Busch Stadium needs renovations. Should St. Louis taxpayers kick in? Cardinals games dropped by Comcast after Bally Sports deal falls through Pro-Palestinian protests block traffic outside Washington University Teen charged with breaking into more than 35 cars in St. Louis County St. Louis County man charged with 1966 Chicago killing, stabbing woman 125 times BenFred: Sunday was a gut-test game for the Cardinals. They failed. Miserably. Target to open this summer in Midtown St. Louis neighborhood Hochman: For Cardinals fans, 'patience' has become a 'trigger word' on social media Governor torpedoes appointment of former mayor in squabble with St. Louis senator Condemnation mounts for Washington University's 'appalling' response to protest BenFred: Here's why it just got harder to recruit against Eli Drinkwitz and Mizzou Media Views: Battlehawks dominate spring football in attendance, but no longer in TV ratings Hundreds gather at SLU to protest war in Gaza. 'It's my university's turn.'\n\nColumbia's decision to cancel its main ceremonies scheduled for May 15 saves its president, Nemat Shafik, from having to deliver a commencement address in the same part of campus where police dismantled a protest encampment last week.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students.\n\n\"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles (8 kilometers) north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nSpeakers at some of Columbia's still-scheduled graduation ceremonies include Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright James Ijames, former CNN anchor Poppy Harlow, political scientist Ian Bremmer and Dr. Monica Bertagnolli, director of the National Institutes of Health. Also, actor Michael J. Fox is scheduled to receive a medal for distinguished service from Columbia's Teachers College.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks.\n\nSimilar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC on Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston on Sunday, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement in Fenway Park.\n\nAt the University of California, Los Angeles, disruptions continued Monday following the dismantling of a pro-Palestinian encampment and some 200 arrests last week. Police detained numerous people in a parking structure. The university also said classes in one building, Monroe Hall, would move online \"due to ongoing disruptions\" but did not provide details.\n\nAlso Monday, police cleared a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of California, San Diego, and arrested more than 30 people, The San Diego Union-Tribune reported.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. Student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nHamas announced Monday that it has accepted an Egyptian-Qatari cease-fire proposal to halt the war in Gaza, but Israel did not immediately comment. Details have not yet been released.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.\n\nEmory's 16,000-student university is one of many that has seen repeated protests over the war.\n\nCeremonies scheduled for May 13 will now be held at the GasSouth Arena and Convocation Center in Duluth, almost 20 miles (30 kilometers) northeast of the university's Atlanta campus, President Gregory Fenves said in an open letter.\n\n\"Please know that this decision was not taken lightly,\" Fenves wrote. \"It was made in close consultation with the Emory Police Department, security advisors and other agencies -- each of which advised against holding commencement events on our campuses.\"\n\nThe university called outside police agencies to arrest 28 people after an encampment was erected on the quad on April 25. After initially claiming the protesters were outsiders, the university later said 20 were Emory students and three were faculty members. Police used pepper balls and electric stun guns to subdue some of the people who were arrested. Fenves later apologized.\n\nProtests have continued on the campus since then, including some additional arrests.\n\nAssociated Press writer Jeff Amy in Atlanta contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"eng-9542834": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8114434460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "20:55:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T20:55:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T20:53:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/partners/ap/national/columbia-university-cancels-main-commencement-after-weeks-of-pro-palestinian-protests/article_b62f2196-e62f-5ba1-9809-5e2ae97af167.html", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests", "body": "By KAREN MATTHEWS - Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Columbia University canceled its large university-wide commencement ceremony Monday following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but said students will still be able to celebrate at a series of smaller, school-based ceremonies this week and next.\n\nThe decision comes as universities around the country are wrangling with how to handle commencements. Another campus shaken by protests, Emory University, announced Monday that it would move its commencement from its campus quadrangle in Atlanta to a suburban arena. But others, including the University of Michigan, Indiana University and Northeastern, have pulled off ceremonies with few disruptions.\n\nWentzville superintendent's departure came after threats and police patrols Washington University faculty placed on leave, students 'houseless' after Gaza protest Busch Stadium needs renovations. Should St. Louis taxpayers kick in? Cardinals games dropped by Comcast after Bally Sports deal falls through Pro-Palestinian protests block traffic outside Washington University Teen charged with breaking into more than 35 cars in St. Louis County St. Louis County man charged with 1966 Chicago killing, stabbing woman 125 times BenFred: Sunday was a gut-test game for the Cardinals. They failed. Miserably. Target to open this summer in Midtown St. Louis neighborhood Hochman: For Cardinals fans, 'patience' has become a 'trigger word' on social media Governor torpedoes appointment of former mayor in squabble with St. Louis senator Condemnation mounts for Washington University's 'appalling' response to protest BenFred: Here's why it just got harder to recruit against Eli Drinkwitz and Mizzou Media Views: Battlehawks dominate spring football in attendance, but no longer in TV ratings Hundreds gather at SLU to protest war in Gaza. 'It's my university's turn.'\n\nColumbia's decision to cancel its main ceremonies scheduled for May 15 saves its president, Nemat Shafik, from having to deliver a commencement address in the same part of campus where police dismantled a protest encampment last week.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students.\n\n\"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles (8 kilometers) north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nSpeakers at some of Columbia's still-scheduled graduation ceremonies include Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright James Ijames, former CNN anchor Poppy Harlow, political scientist Ian Bremmer and Dr. Monica Bertagnolli, director of the National Institutes of Health. Also, actor Michael J. Fox is scheduled to receive a medal for distinguished service from Columbia's Teachers College.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks.\n\nSimilar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC on Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston on Sunday, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement in Fenway Park.\n\nAt the University of California, Los Angeles, disruptions continued Monday following the dismantling of a pro-Palestinian encampment and some 200 arrests last week. Police detained numerous people in a parking structure. The university also said classes in one building, Monroe Hall, would move online \"due to ongoing disruptions\" but did not provide details.\n\nAlso Monday, police cleared a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of California, San Diego, and arrested more than 30 people, The San Diego Union-Tribune reported.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. Student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nHamas announced Monday that it has accepted an Egyptian-Qatari cease-fire proposal to halt the war in Gaza, but Israel did not immediately comment. Details have not yet been released.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.\n\nEmory's 16,000-student university is one of many that has seen repeated protests over the war.\n\nCeremonies scheduled for May 13 will now be held at the GasSouth Arena and Convocation Center in Duluth, almost 20 miles (30 kilometers) northeast of the university's Atlanta campus, President Gregory Fenves said in an open letter.\n\n\"Please know that this decision was not taken lightly,\" Fenves wrote. \"It was made in close consultation with the Emory Police Department, security advisors and other agencies -- each of which advised against holding commencement events on our campuses.\"\n\nThe university called outside police agencies to arrest 28 people after an encampment was erected on the quad on April 25. After initially claiming the protesters were outsiders, the university later said 20 were Emory students and three were faculty members. Police used pepper balls and electric stun guns to subdue some of the people who were arrested. Fenves later apologized.\n\nProtests have continued on the campus since then, including some additional arrests.\n\nAssociated Press writer Jeff Amy in Atlanta contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"eng-9542834": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8114434460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "20:55:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T20:55:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T20:53:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/partners/ap/national/columbia-university-cancels-main-commencement-after-weeks-of-pro-palestinian-protests/article_b62f2196-e62f-5ba1-9809-5e2ae97af167.html", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests", "body": "By KAREN MATTHEWS - Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Columbia University canceled its large university-wide commencement ceremony Monday following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but said students will still be able to celebrate at a series of smaller, school-based ceremonies this week and next.\n\nThe decision comes as universities around the country are wrangling with how to handle commencements. Another campus shaken by protests, Emory University, announced Monday that it would move its commencement from its campus quadrangle in Atlanta to a suburban arena. But others, including the University of Michigan, Indiana University and Northeastern, have pulled off ceremonies with few disruptions.\n\nWentzville superintendent's departure came after threats and police patrols Washington University faculty placed on leave, students 'houseless' after Gaza protest Busch Stadium needs renovations. Should St. Louis taxpayers kick in? Cardinals games dropped by Comcast after Bally Sports deal falls through Pro-Palestinian protests block traffic outside Washington University Teen charged with breaking into more than 35 cars in St. Louis County St. Louis County man charged with 1966 Chicago killing, stabbing woman 125 times BenFred: Sunday was a gut-test game for the Cardinals. They failed. Miserably. Target to open this summer in Midtown St. Louis neighborhood Hochman: For Cardinals fans, 'patience' has become a 'trigger word' on social media Governor torpedoes appointment of former mayor in squabble with St. Louis senator Condemnation mounts for Washington University's 'appalling' response to protest BenFred: Here's why it just got harder to recruit against Eli Drinkwitz and Mizzou Media Views: Battlehawks dominate spring football in attendance, but no longer in TV ratings Hundreds gather at SLU to protest war in Gaza. 'It's my university's turn.'\n\nColumbia's decision to cancel its main ceremonies scheduled for May 15 saves its president, Nemat Shafik, from having to deliver a commencement address in the same part of campus where police dismantled a protest encampment last week.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students.\n\n\"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles (8 kilometers) north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nSpeakers at some of Columbia's still-scheduled graduation ceremonies include Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright James Ijames, former CNN anchor Poppy Harlow, political scientist Ian Bremmer and Dr. Monica Bertagnolli, director of the National Institutes of Health. Also, actor Michael J. Fox is scheduled to receive a medal for distinguished service from Columbia's Teachers College.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks.\n\nSimilar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC on Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston on Sunday, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement in Fenway Park.\n\nAt the University of California, Los Angeles, disruptions continued Monday following the dismantling of a pro-Palestinian encampment and some 200 arrests last week. Police detained numerous people in a parking structure. The university also said classes in one building, Monroe Hall, would move online \"due to ongoing disruptions\" but did not provide details.\n\nAlso Monday, police cleared a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of California, San Diego, and arrested more than 30 people, The San Diego Union-Tribune reported.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. Student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nHamas announced Monday that it has accepted an Egyptian-Qatari cease-fire proposal to halt the war in Gaza, but Israel did not immediately comment. Details have not yet been released.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.\n\nEmory's 16,000-student university is one of many that has seen repeated protests over the war.\n\nCeremonies scheduled for May 13 will now be held at the GasSouth Arena and Convocation Center in Duluth, almost 20 miles (30 kilometers) northeast of the university's Atlanta campus, President Gregory Fenves said in an open letter.\n\n\"Please know that this decision was not taken lightly,\" Fenves wrote. \"It was made in close consultation with the Emory Police Department, security advisors and other agencies -- each of which advised against holding commencement events on our campuses.\"\n\nThe university called outside police agencies to arrest 28 people after an encampment was erected on the quad on April 25. After initially claiming the protesters were outsiders, the university later said 20 were Emory students and three were faculty members. Police used pepper balls and electric stun guns to subdue some of the people who were arrested. Fenves later apologized.\n\nProtests have continued on the campus since then, including some additional arrests.\n\nAssociated Press writer Jeff Amy in Atlanta contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"eng-9542834": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8114435069", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "20:55:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T20:55:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T20:54:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://magicvalley.com/partners/ap/national/columbia-university-cancels-main-commencement-after-weeks-of-pro-palestinian-protests/article_ddd8eb68-5c27-5552-8bf2-c07aa4e2f26b.html", "title": "Columbia University cancels main commencement after weeks of pro-Palestinian protests", "body": "By KAREN MATTHEWS - Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Columbia University canceled its large university-wide commencement ceremony Monday following weeks of pro-Palestinian protests that have roiled its campus and others across the U.S., but said students will still be able to celebrate at a series of smaller, school-based ceremonies this week and next.\n\nThe decision comes as universities around the country are wrangling with how to handle commencements. Another campus shaken by protests, Emory University, announced Monday that it would move its commencement from its campus quadrangle in Atlanta to a suburban arena. But others, including the University of Michigan, Indiana University and Northeastern, have pulled off ceremonies with few disruptions.\n\nPeople are also reading... Distribution center sets grand opening in Jerome Former volunteer coach at Twin Falls school charged with rape Rupert man dies after side-by-side strikes cow Man files lawsuit against Buhl, police chief, contending rights violated in arrest Death Notices Death Notices Death Notices One dead, two injured in Blaine County crash Tactical Games coming to Rupert Turf Club - reimagined BUILDING WITH A VISION: Latino student builds greenhouse for senior project Magic Valley's top 3 baseball, softball performers: April 24-April 30 Valley boys, Murtaugh girls win Snake River Conference track and field titles; prep sports roundup: May 2 Making a difference: Twin Falls deputies honored for life-saving actions Family of Twin Falls High School student-athlete files complaint; alleges physical and emotional hazing\n\nColumbia's decision to cancel its main ceremonies scheduled for May 15 saves its president, Nemat Shafik, from having to deliver a commencement address in the same part of campus where police dismantled a protest encampment last week.\n\nNoting that the past few weeks have been \"incredibly difficult\" for the community, the Ivy League school in upper Manhattan said in its announcement that it made the decision after discussions with students.\n\n\"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" officials said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers.\"\n\nMost of the ceremonies that had been scheduled for the south lawn of the main campus, where encampments were taken down last week, will take place about 5 miles (8 kilometers) north at Columbia's sports complex, officials said.\n\nSpeakers at some of Columbia's still-scheduled graduation ceremonies include Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright James Ijames, former CNN anchor Poppy Harlow, political scientist Ian Bremmer and Dr. Monica Bertagnolli, director of the National Institutes of Health. Also, actor Michael J. Fox is scheduled to receive a medal for distinguished service from Columbia's Teachers College.\n\nColumbia had already canceled in-person classes. More than 200 pro-Palestinian demonstrators who had camped out on Columbia's green or occupied an academic building were arrested in recent weeks.\n\nSimilar encampments sprouted up at universities around the country as schools struggled with where to draw the line between allowing free expression while maintaining safe and inclusive campuses.\n\nThe University of Southern California earlier canceled its main graduation ceremony while allowing other commencement activities to continue. Students abandoned their camp at USC on Sunday after being surrounded by police and threatened with arrest.\n\nOther universities have held their graduation ceremonies with beefed-up security. The University of Michigan's ceremony was interrupted by chanting a few times Saturday, while in Boston on Sunday, some students waved small Palestinian or Israeli flags as Northeastern University held its commencement in Fenway Park.\n\nAt the University of California, Los Angeles, disruptions continued Monday following the dismantling of a pro-Palestinian encampment and some 200 arrests last week. Police detained numerous people in a parking structure. The university also said classes in one building, Monroe Hall, would move online \"due to ongoing disruptions\" but did not provide details.\n\nAlso Monday, police cleared a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of California, San Diego, and arrested more than 30 people, The San Diego Union-Tribune reported.\n\nThe protests stem from the conflict that started Oct. 7 when Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing about 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking roughly 250 hostages. Student protesters are calling on their schools to divest from companies that do business with Israel or otherwise contribute to the war effort.\n\nHamas announced Monday that it has accepted an Egyptian-Qatari cease-fire proposal to halt the war in Gaza, but Israel did not immediately comment. Details have not yet been released.\n\nVowing to destroy Hamas, Israel launched an offensive in Gaza that has killed more than 34,500 Palestinians, about two-thirds of them women and children, according to the Health Ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory. Israeli strikes have devastated the enclave and displaced most of its inhabitants.\n\nEmory's 16,000-student university is one of many that has seen repeated protests over the war.\n\nCeremonies scheduled for May 13 will now be held at the GasSouth Arena and Convocation Center in Duluth, almost 20 miles (30 kilometers) northeast of the university's Atlanta campus, President Gregory Fenves said in an open letter.\n\n\"Please know that this decision was not taken lightly,\" Fenves wrote. \"It was made in close consultation with the Emory Police Department, security advisors and other agencies -- each of which advised against holding commencement events on our campuses.\"\n\nThe university called outside police agencies to arrest 28 people after an encampment was erected on the quad on April 25. After initially claiming the protesters were outsiders, the university later said 20 were Emory students and three were faculty members. Police used pepper balls and electric stun guns to subdue some of the people who were arrested. Fenves later apologized.\n\nProtests have continued on the campus since then, including some additional arrests.\n\nAssociated Press writer Jeff Amy in Atlanta contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"eng-9542834": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8114468538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "21:27:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T21:27:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T21:26:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://balleralert.com/profiles/blogs/columbia-university-replaces-its-commencement-ceremony-with-smaller-scaled-celebrations-following-protests-on-campus/", "title": "Columbia University Replaces Its Commencement Ceremony With \"Smaller-Scaled\" Celebrations Following Protests On Campus", "body": "The university-wide commencement ceremony typically held by Columbia University will have a new look this year.\n\nAccording to reports, Columbia is set to hold \"smaller-scale, school-based celebrations\" instead of its usual graduation ceremony. The institution shared that the decision was made following discussions with student representatives and comes shortly after weeks of pro-Palestinian and opposing protests on campus, which raised security concerns.\n\n\"Our students emphasized that these smaller-scale, school-based celebrations are most meaningful to them and their families,\" the Ivy League university said. \"They are eager to cross the stage to applause and family pride and hear from their school's invited guest speakers. As a result, we will focus our resources on those school ceremonies and on keeping them safe, respectful, and running smoothly.\"\n\nThe school added, \"These past few weeks have been incredibly difficult for our community. Just as we are focused on making our graduation experience truly special, we continue to solicit student feedback and are looking at the possibility of a festive event on May 15 to take the place of the large, formal ceremony. We are eager to all come together for our graduates and celebrate our fellow Columbians as they, and we, look ahead to the future.\"\n\nUnfortunately, students will now be recognized \" individually alongside their peers\" in smaller ceremonies. However, the graduation ceremony is not the only thing affected by the protests. \"Class Days\" and school ceremonies originally scheduled to take place at the south lawn of the Morningside campus, have been moved to Columbia's Baker Athletics Complex.\n\nIf you're unaware, Pro-Palestinian protests popped up on campus last month after students set up roughly 50 tents, calling for a Gaza cease-fire and for the university to end their partnership with companies profiting from the war. On April 30th, New York City police officers arrived on campus in full riot gear and forced their way into Hamilton Hall, where protesters had barricaded themselves. Not long after, about 100 arrests were made, which stirred up some tension, leading Columbia President Minouche Shafik to request police assistance on the campus until May 17th.", "source": {"uri":
